sentences: Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology
HST.071: Human Reproductive Biology
Course Director: Professor Henry Klapholz
HST 071
IN SUMMARY MALE SYSTEM
[H1] MALE SYSTEM ANATOMY.
[H2] TESTIS.
[LIST_ITEM] Testis descends from a retroperitoneal position through the inguinal canal to take to scrotum during the eighth fetal month.
[LIST_ITEM] Lower temperature required for spermatogenesis
[LIST_ITEM] Countercurrent vascular heat exchange system
[LIST_ITEM] Seminiferous tubules comprise 95% of testicular volume,
[LIST_ITEM] 500 tubules per testis.
[LIST_ITEM] Surrounded by the tough tunica albuginea.
[LIST_ITEM] Seminiferous tubules -> rete testis -> epididymis -> vas deferens -> prostate -> ejaculatory duct -> urethra
[LIST_ITEM] Seminal vesicle secretions join sperm in prostate
[LIST_ITEM] Gonad undifferentiated at 8 weeks
[LIST_ITEM] Influence of Y chromosome
[LIST_ITEM] Wollfian duct -> male
[LIST_ITEM] MIS -> regression of Mullerian ducts (uterus and fallopian tube in female)
[LIST_ITEM] Testosterone to DHT by 5 alpha reductase causes masculinization of external genitalia
[H2] SERTOLI CELLS.
[LIST_ITEM] Sertoli cells and germ cells make up the seminiferous tubules
[LIST_ITEM] Tight junctions between Sertoli cells (blood-testis barrier)
[LIST_ITEM] Sertoli cells separate germinal epithelium into basal and adluminal compartments.
[LIST_ITEM] Single Sertoli cell envelopes up to 20 germ cells
[LIST_ITEM] Sertoli cells: support and nutrition of germ cells, release of mature germ cells, secrete androgen binding protein, transferring, inhibin, cell-cell communication (gap junctions)
[H2] GERM CELLS.
[LIST_ITEM] Spermatogonia – line basement layer of seminiferous tubules – small, round, mitotically active
[LIST_ITEM] Develop into type B spermatogonia -> primary spermatocytes during first meiotic division (tetraploid)
[LIST_ITEM] Pre-leptotene, leptotene, zygotene, pachytene, diplotene
[LIST_ITEM] Secondary spermatocytes result from first reduction division (diploid)
[LIST_ITEM] Second meiotic division lasts a day and result in spermatids (haploid)
[LIST_ITEM] Cells in any cluster are synchronized
[H2] SPERMATOZOA.
[LIST_ITEM] Morphologically mature – highly polarized – 60 uM
[LIST_ITEM] Condensed nucleus (acrosome) and membrane
[LIST_ITEM] Tail – has neck, mid piece (sheath of mitochondria), principle piece, end piece
[LIST_ITEM] 9+2 axoneme extends from neck to end piece
[LIST_ITEM] Entire tail covered by plasma membrane
[H2] LEYDIG CELLS.
[LIST_ITEM] Between seminiferous tubules
[LIST_ITEM] Production of testosterone – local and distant purposes
[LIST_ITEM] In testes, testosterone bound to androgen binding protein secreted by Sertoli cells
[LIST_ITEM] In plasma, testosterone is bound to circulating testosterone binding globulin
[H2] SEMEN.
[LIST_ITEM] Suspension of sperm in seminal plasma
[LIST_ITEM] Seminal plasma: seminal vesicles, prostate and also bulbourethral gland (Cowper's), urethral glands (Littre), rete testis, epididymis, vas deferens, ampullae
[LIST_ITEM] Seminiferous tubules drain to mediastinum testes and then into rete testis where 90% of fluid is produced
[LIST_ITEM] 8-12 efferent ducts from rete testis to epididymis
IN SUMMARY MALE SYSTEM
HST 071
[H1] EPIDIDYMUS.
[LIST_ITEM] 20 meter long duct, pseudostratified columnar epithelium, cilia
[LIST_ITEM] Sperm conduit, fluid resorption, sperm reservoir (cauda), sperm maturation (fertilizing ability and motility)
[H1] VAS DEFERENS.
[LIST_ITEM] Continuation of epididymis
[LIST_ITEM] Straight duct, pseudostratified columnar epithelium, cilia, 25-45 cm long
[LIST_ITEM] Transport of sperm through scrotum, inguinal canal, behind base of bladder (ampullae)
[LIST_ITEM] Thick muscular wall for rapid transport of sperm during ejaculation
[H1] PROSTATE.
[LIST_ITEM] 20 grams
[H1] EJACULATE.
[LIST_ITEM] 2-5 cc with 150-200 million sperm
[H1] HORMONAL CONTROL OF SPERMEOGENESIS.
[LIST_ITEM] Testosterone (for germinal epithelium), FSH (stimulates Sertoli cells to make protein kinases and protein synthesis)
[LIST_ITEM] LH stimulates Leydig cells to make testosterone
[LIST_ITEM] GnRH made in hypothalamus – pulses every 70-90 minutes – half life 2-5 minutes
[LIST_ITEM] Testosterone inhibits LH release from pituitary and GnRH release from hypothalamus
[LIST_ITEM] Estradiol derived from aromatase conversion of testosterone
[LIST_ITEM] Estradiol more potent inhibitor of LH and FSH
[LIST_ITEM] FSH secretion down regulated by inhibin (made by Sertoli cells)
[H1] SPERM PHYSIOLOGY.
[LIST_ITEM] Traverse female genital tract, bind to ova, penetrate zona pellucida, fuses with plasma membrane of ovum
[LIST_ITEM] Fresh ejaculate is gel (made in seminal vesicles), liquefies in 5-20 minutes (by prostate protease)
[LIST_ITEM] Fructose (seminal vesicles) is energy substrate for sperm
[LIST_ITEM] Capacitation -> acrosome reaction, release of lysosomal enzymes, alter plasma membrane of sperm head, affects sperms stickiness to egg, cause hypermotility, change in tail beat frequency
[H1] MALE INFERTILITY EVALUATION.
[LIST_ITEM] History
[LIST_ITEM] Prior history of infertility, timing of puberty, genital abnormalities, medications, prior surgery, chronic illness
[LIST_ITEM] Physical exam
[LIST_ITEM] Evidence of endocrine abnormalities->gynecomastia, hair pattern, phallus, urethral meatus, size and consistency of testes (4.5 cm diameter), vas deference, varicocele
[H1] SEMEN ANALYSIS.
[LIST_ITEM] Volume 2-5 cc
[LIST_ITEM] Sperm density >20 million/cc (avg. 50-60)
[LIST_ITEM] Motility >60%
[LIST_ITEM] Morphology Absence of WBC's, RBC's, bacteria, agglutination
[LIST_ITEM] >60% normal forms
[H1] VARICOCELE.
[LIST_ITEM] Dilated pampiniform plexus, left side, 10-15% of all men, 50% of infertility patients
IN SUMMARY MALE SYSTEM
[LIST_ITEM] Abnormal thermoregulation
[LIST_ITEM] Testes usually 20 degrees C cooler than core temperature
[LIST_ITEM] Ligation of gonadal vein, improves sperm quality in 70% of men
[H1] EJACULATION – ERECTION.
[LIST_ITEM] Emission (deposition of sperm into posterior urethra) and expulsion from urethra
[LIST_ITEM] Under control of sympathetic nervous system
[LIST_ITEM] Emission – contractions of vas, seminal vesicles and prostate
[LIST_ITEM] Ejaculation – closure of bladder neck and contraction of periurethral muscles, bulbocavernosus
[LIST_ITEM] Point and shoot
[H1] ERECTION.
[LIST_ITEM] Neurologic initiation, reflex or centrally mediated
[LIST_ITEM] Arterial filling of erectile bodies – corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
[LIST_ITEM] Venous occlusion of erectile bodies
[LIST_ITEM] Flaccid state – resting sympathetic tone, small caliber cavernosal arteries and contracted muscle

[LIST_ITEM] Signal for erection – relaxation of arterioles, increased caliber, relaxation of cervervosal sinusoids, venules are compressed by inflow of blood and increased intracorporal pressure causing reduced outflow
[LIST_ITEM] When sympathetic tone returns the arteries constrict and the veins allow outflow
[H1] VIAGRA AND SIMILAR DRUGS.
[LIST_ITEM] Sildenafil and many others
[LIST_ITEM] NO (nitric oxide) released in corpus cavernosum during sexual stimulation
[LIST_ITEM] NO->guanylate cyclase->cGMP->smooth muscle relaxation->blood flow
[LIST_ITEM] Sildenafil enhances effect of NO by inhibiting type 5 phosphodiesterase (degrades cGMP)
[LIST_ITEM] Has no effect in absence of sexual stimulation
[LIST_ITEM] Most potent effect on PDE5 (4000 times that for PDE3)
[LIST_ITEM] Also affects PDE6 found in retina (color vision problems with high dose)
[LIST_ITEM] Hepatic metabolism (cytochrome P450) – active metabolite
[LIST_ITEM] Caution if using other P450 inhibitors (itraconazole, ketoconazole, erythromycin, ritonavir, cimetidine)
[LIST_ITEM] Rapidly absorbed, maximum plasma concentration within 30-40 minutes
[LIST_ITEM] Decrease in supine BP
IN SUMMARY MALE SYSTEM HST 071
[H1] FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Where are sperm produced?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is a Sertoli cell? A Leydig cell?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] In what cell in the testes is testosterone synthesized?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] On what cell does FSH act? LH?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is the function of the epididymis?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is the function of the seminal vesicles?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What causes the undifferentiated gonad to differentiate into the males testes?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is semen made of?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Describe the structure of a sperm? What is the acrosome? The midpiece? How does the tail move?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What do Cowper's glands do?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] When a man has a vasectomy what comes out when he ejaculates? What test would one do on a woman who states she was raped in order to prove ejaculation occurred in her vagina?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Describe the contribution of the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems to ejaculation.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is the role of the prostate gland? If a man has had a prostatectomy can he make a woman pregnant?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] How does Sildenafil (VIAGRA) work?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What are some of the significant side effects and contraindications of VIAGRA?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is the range of normal sperm count for a male?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is the volume of an average ejaculate?
